caseTitle: OPANIN KWABENA BOAKYE v. FRANCIS MANU
summary: The Supreme Court of Ghana dismissed an application for review filed by Opanin Kwabena Boakye against Francis Manu, holding that the application did not meet the required threshold for review jurisdiction. The Court emphasized that review is not an appeal and is only permissible under exceptional circumstances demonstrating a miscarriage of justice. The issues raised were found to be a rehash of those previously considered by the Ordinary Bench, with no new grounds warranting review. All justices concurred with the dismissal.
rationaleHighlights: Review is not an appeal and limited to exceptional circumstances
Raised issues were already considered by the Ordinary Bench
Arguments were a rehash of prior submissions
Preference for minority opinion does not justify review
Finality of judicial decisions must be respected
Concurrence by all justices affirms procedural correctness
